title: Lib Dems 'agree to STAND ASIDE' in favour of ex-Tory Dominic Grieve as a Remain Alliance candidate
text:
Rebel ex-Tory Dominic Grieve will be given a free run by the Lib Dems at the next election, paving the way for him to stand as a Remain Alliance candidate.

The former attorney general, now an independent, says he will run again in his Beaconsfield seat in a vote expected this side of Christmas shaping up to be a Brexit v Remain battle.

The Lib Dem candidate, teacher and musician Rob Castell, agreed to drop out to avoid taking Remain votes away from Mr Grieve in a seat that voted 51-49 to stay in the EU in 2016.

Mr Grieve took the seat in 2017 for the Tories with a majority of 24,543 from Labour in second.

The Lib Dems were third with just 4,448 votes, but he will be hoping also to take votes from Labour as its Brexit policy is in disarray.

'If there is going to be a general election prior to Brexit being concluded my view is that, in those circumstances, if I can't stand as a Conservative candidate I will stand as an independent,' Mr Grieve told the Sunday Times.

'It's up to other political parties to decide whether they wish to put up a candidate.

'My understanding is that the Liberal Democrats will decide not to do so, for which I am grateful. I believe that will be helpful.

Mr Grieve took the seat in 2017 for the Tories with a majority of 24,543 from Labour in second, but lost the party whip last month

Jo Swinson's party has moved to backing overtly back reversing the 2016 referendum result if it wins the next election

'I have also had supportive emails from people who voted Labour in 2017.'

Mr Grieve was one of 21 Tory MPs who lost the party whip last month after voting for the Benn Act, which ties Boris Johnson's hands over Brexit.

He had also been threatened with de-selection by his local party over his attempts to soften Brexit.

The proposed free run for a sole Remain candidate comes after a similar plan was enacted for the Brecon and Radnorshire by-election.

The Green party and Plaid Cymru did not run, allowing the Lib Dem Jane Dodds to take the seat from expenses cheat Tory Chris Davies in August.

A Lib Dem spokesman said that the decision in Beaconsfield was still in the balance.

'Given our commitment to stop Brexit, we are working to make sure we have the maximum number of Remainers in Parliament.

'In most places that will be the Liberal Democrats. So, it's fair to say that there are a lot of these discussions happening across the country. In this instance, as with other seats, it's too early to say an agreement is a done deal.'
description: The former attorney general, now an independent, says he will run in his Beaconsfield seat in a vote expected this side of Christmas shaping up to be a Brexit v Remain battle.
